content.value: to help you figure out who you are and what kind of life/business you need to build if you’re going to be truly free. This week is all about SAVING. Why? Well, let me illustrate by jumping back in time a few years to when I was still slaving away in the corporate world…

I’ve been working as a copywriter at an agency in NJ for more than a year. I hate it; it’s absolutely soul-crushing. The clients are evil and/or boring, the meetings never end, the culture is toxic, and, worst of all, the job is a dead-end with no potential for growth. I need to get out, but I’m expending so much energy just trying to SURVIVE on a day-to-day basis that I have absolutely nothing left in the tank. I’m stuck in a vicious cycle.
I know that all you can think about right now is trying to make a break from the 9–5 world, and I’m here to tell you that it’s definitely
BUT…you won’t get very far if you don’t have enough time, money, and energy to make a solid plan. And, trust me, you’re going to need WAY MORE than you think.
you need? And how can you save it up?

Investors and other business folk like to ask the question: “What’s your number?” In other words, how much money do you need to be happy? You might be thinking…damn, what a shallow way to measure happiness. You’re right.
. But, as you’ll see, the resources we’re talking about in this post are all interconnected.
Time is money, money is energy, and energy is happiness.

number is important. For now, though, I want you to focus on a much smaller number: the minimum amount of money you need to survive the next six months. We’re going to calculate this by doing some good-old-fashioned personal accounting. Bear in mind, the smaller you can make this number, the sooner you’re going to be able to escape.
high overhead = less freedom = slow growth.
Taking stock of your monthly expenses
First, let’s create a spreadsheet to record our findings. You can use
, or any other tool you prefer. Log into your bank account and pull up any transactions from last month. Add all your
Next, zoom out to the last three months. For each
(like gas or groceries), add up what you spent, then divide by three to get the average. Drop these in your table, as well. Do a quick brain scan for anything you might have missed.

You now have a list of everything you spend money on, and it’s time to go hunting. For each item on the list, ask yourself: Can I live without this thing for the next six months while I’m grinding on my new ventures? Create a “Non-Essential” column in your table and check off any expenses you can lose. Here are some prime suspects:
Dining out (I’m looking at you, “business lunch”)
Driving everywhere vs walking or biking

Rent is another common expense, but ditching that usually requires some big decisions. If you think you might be able to live at home, mark any apartment-related expenses as non-essential for now, and we’ll come back to them later in this post.

Now that you have your table categorized by importance, add up all the essential items. Where did you land? Back in 2015, I got my expenses down to around $750/mo, which meant I could quit my job and start freelancing full-time.

In addition to monthly expenses, it’s also important to factor in how much money you’re going to have saved up before you quit. Fortunately, I had about $5,000 in the bank when I finally decided to quit. UN-fortunately, there were were still four months left on my lease, so I was practically broke by the time I moved home.

I don’t regret taking the plunge, but the question of WHEN to quit is going to come down to how risk-averse you are and how badly you want to escape your current situation. Saving up enough money to live on for six months will put you in a better position to start freelancing or create a passive income business — clients and customers can smell desperation like sharks can smell blood in the water.

Because I needed money so badly in the beginning, I took on clients I shouldn’t have…and ended up working for pennies. Of course, this is part of the learning process, but too many failures can leave you in a emotional hole that’s hard to climb out of.
If you struggled just to carve out enough time to write a
last week, then it’s going to be difficult for you to launch a side hustle, let alone scale it into a full-on freedom business that allows you live the kind of life you’re imagining.

The good news is you probably have a lot more time than you think you do. Let’s find out by using the same process we applied to our monthly expenses. Yup, you guessed it: we need to create another table. Here’s my list…

I was occupied for 157 hours out of a potential 168 hours per week, which left me with 11 hours — around 1.5 hours per day. Mind you, those were LOW-QUALITY hours, because I was already mentally exhausted from working at a job I hated all day.
How’s your list looking? Pretty brutal? That’s ok, because we’re about to wave a magic wand and free up the time you need to start working on a better life.

I’m guessing the biggest time block on your list is your full-time job. Along with your expenses and savings, it’s important to factor in how emotionally taxing your current position is (aka “meh” or “I fucking hate this, get me out of here right now”). You should also consider how much potential there is for you to develop relevant skills.

My copywriting job was literally sucking the life out of me. Worse, because the agency was so hierarchical and conservative, I couldn’t learn by trial-and-error. That lack of entrepreneurial freedom slowed my personal development down to a snail’s pace.

If you’re learning a lot at your current job and it isn’t too stressful, then you might want to stay on full-time for a year or two…just don’t get too comfy (unless golden handcuffs turn out to be your thing).

Asking you boss to work from home or scale back to part-time hours can be a good middle ground if you’re not ready to freelance full-time. Ideally, you want to be bringing in $1,000/mo or more before you decide to quit for good.

You know what’s coming in this section. While quitting your job might be a relief, cutting out the fun stuff won’t be so easy. If you’re looking for some motivation and you have ten minutes or so to spare, watch
, where Chris Do (Blind CEO and business coach) helps Sean Campbell (a young gun designer) figure out how to go from a gas station attendant to an in-demand logo expert.

title.en-US: Chris Do and Sean Campbell: how to free up time and energy

content.value: Now that you’re fired up, go through your time table and cross off anything that’s nonessential to your personal growth. If you absolutely cannot give something up (Game of Thrones, etc), turn it into a once-a-week reward for completing key goals. When I moved home in March of 2016, I gave up video games, movies, hanging out with friends, and (of course) my full-time job:

Overall, I managed to free up 90 hours per week — the feeling of being back in control of my life had an unbelievably positive effect on my level of motivation and productivity. Those first few months, I would practically jump out of bed in the morning (like it was Christmas), because I couldn’t wait get to the computer and start designing or writing code.
How much time did you carve back into your life? Tweet it to me

Remember when I told you how starting a freelance career without any money saved can put you in a bad spot? Well, a few months after I quit my job and moved home, my bank account was down under a hundred dollars and it seemed like I wouldn’t even make it through the month.

One of my clients needed to publish an illustrated book for her company, so I jumped at the opportunity. I had almost no experience with illustration or print design, but I thought I could learn on the job. It ended up being way more difficult than I imagined, and the stress, combined with a couple deaths in my family, pitched me over the edge.

Ultimately, I realized that the things I thought were giving me energy (YouTube, browsing design inspiration, arguing on Reddit) were actually sucking me dry. Three years later, I started F the Lines, and one of my first posts was on
. You can read it if you want the whole story, but I’m going to summarize the main points here.
There’s a lot of confusion around what creative block actually is, but I think it’s pretty simple:
Creative block is a shortage of mental energy that results from consistently inputting more than you output.

If you had a rough time trying to decide what to cut out of your life in the “Saving Time” section, then revisit it with this filter in mind. If you’re doing something active (cooking, running, learning new techniques), keep doing it; if you’re passively consuming something, stop — or, at least, turn it into a less frequent reward for completing goals.
We’ve caught a lot of obvious time leeches, already. But some of the worst offenders can be more sneaky. Let’s say you procrastinate doing the dishes. Even though you’re technically not
anything, every time you walk by the dishes, your brain has to think about them and then make a decision to ignore them. Not to quote
If you choose not to decide, you still have made a choice.

That tiny interaction isn’t enough to tax your brain. HOWEVER, multiply that by the number of times you walk through the kitchen (not to mention all the other things you put off), and it becomes clear how much energy you’re wasting. Your brain has a limited budget, and like spending real money, you can be a millionaire and still go broke making tiny purchases all day long.
we spend our time, we can also change what we
about the time we spend. The default for most creative people is to criticize their work: “Nothing I do is good enough.” This
acts as a stop sign — halting progress and inducing creative block.
A more effective strategy is to treat self-criticism as a railroad switch: “I did something creative, and here are two ways I could make it even better.” The idea is to use the “

” rule (a la improvisational comedy) to continually slingshot yourself forward, instead of getting stuck. By lowering the bar for “creative” and “output,” you can bypass the punishing critic and actually end up with a much higher-quality result than you thought was possible.

Whether you decide to quit your job now, go part-time, or stay on for a couple more years, the strategies we talked about today are essential to staying productive and creative. Rather than fluid and infinite, I want you to start thinking of your time, money, and energy as limited resources that you need to protect and spend wisely.
Store the tables you made today somewhere safe, and keep reviewing or adding to them as your priorities change. If you want to take a deeper dive into managing your day-to-day energy, you can read
on how I learned to slay creative block for good.

It took me almost four years to figure out how to funnel my freelance work into a profitable business model. Like a lot of creative “entrepreneurs,” I did things completely backwards — but I want help you grow 10x faster. So, next week we’re going to be talking about how to properly start a business. The first step is defining your target audience. Psyched? Me too.
So look out for that email. The subject line is “Defining your target audience.” If you’re not already subscribed to the
to get weekly updates with 100% actionable advice sent straight to your inbox.
If you’re ready to start making some serious changes and pursue the life you want, let’s connect. You can get weekly advice by subscribing to the Framework Journey series

page.title: How to Escape Your 9–5 Job By Saving Time, Money & Energy

summary.text: Whether you're trying to start freelancing or level up an existing business, there are three resources you need to make the leap. Here's how to save them.
